title: How to Make Gluten‐Free Multi‐Purpose Dough

steps.headline: Mix your flours, baking powder, and salt together.
steps.description: Using a whisk or a fork, mix the 244 grams (2 cups) of tapioca flour, 96 grams (1 cup) of almond flour, 6.9 grams (1½ tsp) of baking powder, and 2.8 grams (½ tsp) of salt in a large mixing bowl. Work out any clumps and continue to mix it together until all of the ingredients are well incorporated.

steps.headline: Make a basin in the center of your flour.
steps.description: Create a basin by pushing the flour to the sides of the bowl so that there is a space for your eggs.

steps.headline: Crack your eggs in the middle of the basin and mix.
steps.description: Crack large eggs containing the egg white and the yolk into your flour basin. Mix the dry and wet ingredients together using a fork and continue to mix it until it starts to firm up.

steps.headline: Knead the dough on a flat surface.
steps.description: Pour your mixture onto a flat surface that's been dusted with flour. Knead the dough with your hands and work out the remaining clumps. If the dough is too crumbly, add some water to it until it becomes smooth. If the dough is too wet and sticky, add more tapioca flour to your hands and continue to knead.

steps.headline: Cover and chill the dough until you need it.
steps.description: Once the dough firms up, form it into a ball and place it in a large bowl in your refrigerator for at least two hours. You can use this dough in a variety of recipes including bread, dumplings, and cinnamon rolls. You can keep the dough in the refrigerator for three to five days, covered. If you plan on using a week or more in advance, make sure to freeze it.

steps.headline: Whisk the white rice flour, sweet rice flour, and salt together.
steps.description: Dump your 113.3 grams (1 cup) of white rice flour, 35.4 grams (1/4 cup) of sweet rice flour, and 2.8 grams (1/2 teaspoon) salt in a large mixing bowl. Use a whisk to mix the dry ingredients together until well incorporated. You could also use a sifter to sift the flour together.

steps.headline: Pulse the butter, sugar, and vanilla together.
steps.description: In a food processor or electric mixer pulse the 113.3 grams (1 stick) of butter, 70.9 grams (1/3 cup) of granulated sugar, and 10 ml (2 teaspoons) of vanilla extract together. Continue to do this for about fifteen seconds or until all of the butter has softened and mixed with the sugar and vanilla. Let your butter sit at room temperature to soften it initially.

steps.headline: Add the dry ingredients to your processor and pulse.
steps.description: In small batches, slowly add your dry ingredients into the food processor and set it to medium. Allow some of the flour to incorporate with the wet ingredients, then add more of your flour mixture. Continue to dump the flour mixture until all of it is in your food processor.

steps.headline: Scrape the sides and mix on medium until it forms a dough.
steps.description: Stop pulsing and scrape the dough that gets stuck on the sides of your food processor. Reattach the mixture to the processor and continue mixing it together until it forms a sticky dough. If your dough is too crumbly for your liking, you can add one egg to the mixture to make the dough more malleable.

steps.headline: Knead the dough on a hard surface.
steps.description: Remove your dough from the food processor and knead it with your hands. If the dough is too sticky, you can use some more rice flour so that it's easier to knead. If the dough is too crumbly, try adding a bit of water to make it smoother.

steps.headline: Place the dough in a greased bowl and chill for two hours.
steps.description: Form the dough into a ball before putting it into a bowl covered with plastic wrap. Chilling the dough will allow it to set and harden, making it easier to work with when you decide to make your pastries. This sweet dough should stay good for 3-5 days refrigerated and covered. Your cookie dough is bad when it begins to darken in color and smells rancid.

steps.headline: Mix flour, buttermilk, baking powder, xanthan gum, and salt together.
steps.description: Combine the 224g (1.5 cups) of gluten-free multi-purpose flour, 21g (2 tablespoons) buttermilk powder, 4.6g (1 teaspoon) baking powder, 4.27g (3/4 teaspoon) salt and 3g (1 teaspoon) xanthan gum in a mixing bowl. Continue to mix until all of the ingredients are combined.

steps.headline: Place your yeast and honey in water and set aside.
steps.description: If you have a bowl for your food mixer, you should use the same bowl for your yeast and water solution. Set the yeast aside for 30 minutes. The yeast should look bubbly on the surface when it's ready.

steps.headline: Mix the ingredients in a mixer until it starts to form a dough.
steps.description: Combine all of the wet and dry ingredients in the bowl for your stand mixer. Mix your dough on medium, and it should start to come together and be less sticky. When adding the dry ingredients to the bowl, turn your mixer off and do it slowly so that flour doesn't get everywhere.

steps.headline: Transfer your dough to a bowl and chill for two hours.
steps.description: Once your dough is smooth and no longer sticky, transfer it to a greased pan or bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Set the bowl in the refrigerator for least two hours.

text: Creating Tapioca Multi-Purpose Dough Mix your flours, baking powder, and salt together. Using a whisk or a fork, mix the 244 grams (2 cups) of tapioca flour, 96 grams (1 cup) of almond flour, 6.9 grams (1½ tsp) of baking powder, and 2.8 grams (½ tsp) of salt in a large mixing bowl. Work out any clumps and continue to mix it together until all of the ingredients are well incorporated. Make a basin in the center of your flour. Create a basin by pushing the flour to the sides of the bowl so that there is a space for your eggs. Crack your eggs in the middle of the basin and mix. Crack large eggs containing the egg white and the yolk into your flour basin. Mix the dry and wet ingredients together using a fork and continue to mix it until it starts to firm up. Knead the dough on a flat surface. Pour your mixture onto a flat surface that's been dusted with flour. Knead the dough with your hands and work out the remaining clumps. If the dough is too crumbly, add some water to it until it becomes smooth. If the dough is too wet and sticky, add more tapioca flour to your hands and continue to knead. Cover and chill the dough until you need it. Once the dough firms up, form it into a ball and place it in a large bowl in your refrigerator for at least two hours. You can use this dough in a variety of recipes including bread, dumplings, and cinnamon rolls. You can keep the dough in the refrigerator for three to five days, covered. If you plan on using a week or more in advance, make sure to freeze it. Making Sweet Dessert Dough Whisk the white rice flour, sweet rice flour, and salt together. Dump your 113.3 grams (1 cup) of white rice flour, 35.4 grams (1/4 cup) of sweet rice flour, and 2.8 grams (1/2 teaspoon) salt in a large mixing bowl. Use a whisk to mix the dry ingredients together until well incorporated. You could also use a sifter to sift the flour together. Pulse the butter, sugar, and vanilla together. In a food processor or electric mixer pulse the 113.3 grams (1 stick) of butter, 70.9 grams (1/3 cup) of granulated sugar, and 10 ml (2 teaspoons) of vanilla extract together. Continue to do this for about fifteen seconds or until all of the butter has softened and mixed with the sugar and vanilla. Let your butter sit at room temperature to soften it initially. Add the dry ingredients to your processor and pulse. In small batches, slowly add your dry ingredients into the food processor and set it to medium. Allow some of the flour to incorporate with the wet ingredients, then add more of your flour mixture. Continue to dump the flour mixture until all of it is in your food processor. Scrape the sides and mix on medium until it forms a dough. Stop pulsing and scrape the dough that gets stuck on the sides of your food processor. Reattach the mixture to the processor and continue mixing it together until it forms a sticky dough. If your dough is too crumbly for your liking, you can add one egg to the mixture to make the dough more malleable. Knead the dough on a hard surface. Remove your dough from the food processor and knead it with your hands. If the dough is too sticky, you can use some more rice flour so that it's easier to knead. If the dough is too crumbly, try adding a bit of water to make it smoother. Place the dough in a greased bowl and chill for two hours. Form the dough into a ball before putting it into a bowl covered with plastic wrap. Chilling the dough will allow it to set and harden, making it easier to work with when you decide to make your pastries. This sweet dough should stay good for 3-5 days refrigerated and covered. Your cookie dough is bad when it begins to darken in color and smells rancid. Making Gluten Free Pizza Dough Mix flour, buttermilk, baking powder, xanthan gum, and salt together. Combine the 224g (1.5 cups) of gluten-free multi-purpose flour, 21g (2 tablespoons) buttermilk powder, 4.6g (1 teaspoon) baking powder, 4.27g (3/4 teaspoon) salt and 3g (1 teaspoon) xanthan gum in a mixing bowl. Continue to mix until all of the ingredients are combined. Place your yeast and honey in water and set aside. If you have a bowl for your food mixer, you should use the same bowl for your yeast and water solution. Set the yeast aside for 30 minutes. The yeast should look bubbly on the surface when it's ready. Mix the ingredients in a mixer until it starts to form a dough. Combine all of the wet and dry ingredients in the bowl for your stand mixer. Mix your dough on medium, and it should start to come together and be less sticky. When adding the dry ingredients to the bowl, turn your mixer off and do it slowly so that flour doesn't get everywhere. Transfer your dough to a bowl and chill for two hours. Once your dough is smooth and no longer sticky, transfer it to a greased pan or bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Set the bowl in the refrigerator for least two hours.
